 DEPRESSION IN PREGNANCY, SERIOUS BUT TREATABLE

 By LOIS B. MORRIS  
 c. 2000 New York Times  
 World rights  

   Gina Tretter, a 35-year-old St. Louis dietitian, became so
profoundly depressed after the birth of her long-desired daughter,
Katie, that she swore to her husband, ``We're never doing this
again.'' Although antidepressants finally brought her out of it,
she wouldn't take the risk of having another baby for four more
years. What changed her mind was her doctor's promise that if she
became depressed again _ even during her pregnancy _ she could go
back on the medication.

   Last fall, on Zoloft, she gave birth to Brian. ``I was in love
with him from the first minute,'' said Tretter, who still regrets
that Katie was deprived of that bond for nearly five months, until
Tretter was stabilized on Zoloft and could take her first child to
her heart.

   Few experts deny that antidepressants can alleviate the sadness,
confusion, anger, insomnia, self-recrimination, dread and loss of
interest in virtually everything _ including the baby _ of
postpartum depression. Nor do they deny that antidepressants can
lift a depression during pregnancy. Yet many mental health
professionals and women's health advocates worry that these drugs
are being overprescribed, especially to pregnant and breast-feeding
women.

   ``Many psychiatrists are aggressively treating pregnant women
with psychotropic medications when brief, nonpharmacological
interventions may be equally effective,'' said Michael O'Hara, a
psychology professor at the University of Iowa in Iowa City.

   Some widely respected psychiatrists hold similar views. Many are
old enough to remember the limbless babies born to mothers who took
thalidomide in the 1950s and early '60s to control morning
sickness, and the vaginal and testicular cancers that eventually
developed in children of mothers who took DES (diethylstilbestrol)
from the '40s through the '60s to prevent miscarriage.

   The most commonly prescribed antidepressants, including the
tricyclic class and the newer selective serotonin reuptake
inhibitors, or SSRIs (Prozac, on the market for more than a decade,
has been the most studied), reveal no major birth defects.
``Minor'' anomalies, including oddly shaped earlobes and differing
width of the eyes, have occurred, however. Some premature and
low-birthweight babies have also been reported.

   Katherine L. Wisner, a psychiatrist at Case Western Reserve
University School of Medicine in Cleveland, recently reported on
four studies comparing the birth outcomes of women who had taken
various antidepressants to those of women who had not. They found
no adverse effects on the behavior, temperament, learning abilities
or intelligence of the children, some of whom were followed to
their early school years. But beyond that age, no one knows, and
many of the antidepressants in use are new, with little or no
available data to guide decisions.

   For Tretter, the decision to take a potentially risky drug was
easy: She would do anything to prevent the hell she and her family
went through with her first pregnancy.

   Although the mood swings and teariness of the so-called baby
blues affect up to 80 percent of mothers within the first days of
giving birth, this reactive state usually disappears within a week.

   Any time in that first year, however, 10 percent to 15 percent
of women develop a postpartum depression that meets clinical
criteria; another 5 percent or 10 percent experience an extended
period of bothersome symptoms. One or two in 1,000 develop
postpartum psychosis, the state in which infanticide and suicide
are most common.

   Although women are most prone to depression throughout their
reproductive years, in the first six months after the birth of a
child ``the vulnerability is higher than any other half-year period
of a woman's life,'' said Dr. Nada L. Stotland, a professor of
psychiatry at Rush Medical College in Chicago.

   Like most depressions that a woman endures, this too shall pass
_ eventually. Without intervention, postpartum depression can last
from eight months to more than a year, or it may never resolve
completely. Any depression that is untreated means another is more
likely in the future. Among women who have had one postpartum
depression, the chances increase sevenfold that it will happen in a
succeeding pregnancy.

   Perhaps the most alarming consequence is the depressed new
mother's inability to bond with and nurture her child. Studies show
that infants of depressed mothers are slower to interact with
people and objects. They may have poor motor skills and trouble
regulating their emotions. By age 1, they perform comparatively
poorly on tests of cognitive abilities.

   ``Babies whose mothers were depressed are also at increased risk
of depression throughout life,'' Stotland said. ``How much is
genetic and how much is because these babies spend their early
months looking at tears on a human face, we don't know.''

   For these reasons, mental health practitioners are eager to
treat pregnant women, even to prescribe antidepressants throughout
all three trimesters of pregnancy as well as during breast-feeding.

   ``It's not as if untreated psychiatric disorder is a benign
phenomenon,'' said Dr. Lee S. Cohen, a Harvard psychiatrist who is
the director of the Perinatal and Reproductive Psychiatry Clinical
Research Program at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
``Severe untreated depression and anxiety during pregnancy are
associated with bad fetal outcome, including high rates of
obstetrical complications and preterm labor.''

   A recent study by Dr. Tapio Kurki, a Finnish
obstetrician-gynecologist, of 623 healthy women pregnant for the
first time found 2.5 times as much risk in developing
pre-eclampsia, a sometimes fatal rise in blood pressure, among
women who were anxious or depressed early in pregnancy. And, as
experts uniformly point out, depressed and anxious pregnant women
do not eat or sleep well, exercise or otherwise take care of
themselves.

   ``There are worse things than taking medication during
pregnancy,'' said Dell of Duke, noting that it may be less harmful
for the fetus to be exposed to medication than to be awash for nine
months in the mother's stress hormones. According to the latest
thinking among medical experts, some women are especially sensitive
to normal hormonal cycling. Estrogen and progesterone and other
reproductive hormones are known to affect brain neurotransmitters,
including serotonin, which regulate mood.

   Sudden shifts in these hormones _ occurring most drastically
within 24 hours of the placenta's breaking free after childbirth _
are believed to touch off postpartum depression among women who are
sensitive to changes in serotonin. Thus antidepressants, which
affect neurotransmitter systems, are currently the drugs of choice.

   Even so, no treatment protocols list medication as the first
choice, unless the mother has severe mental illness and she or her
fetus, or both, are at risk.

   Because symptoms of postpartum depression are not uncommon in
mothers of newly adopted children (and in fathers as well), the
biological argument for medication does not hold up fully.

   Psychological and social factors, including relationship
discord, history of child abuse, lack of preparation for motherhood
and changes in a woman's role once she becomes a mother are risk
factors for depression. The absence of support from friends and
family contributes as well.

   Diane Sanford, president of the Women's Healthcare Partnership,
a behavioral health practice in St. Louis, and the psychologist
whom Tretter consulted during her first postpartum depression and
again during her second pregnancy, contends that doctors are too
quick to medicate women. ``That's true of women's health care in
general,'' she said.

   But Sanford supported Tretter's decision to take
antidepressants, given her history. Sanford, a coauthor with Anne
Dunnewold of ``Postpartum Survival Guide,'' said that these
medications are among the options, including psychotherapy, from
which women should be entitled to choose.

   In reality, the choice might be made by default. ``Most women
don't get psychotherapy, because nobody pays for it anymore,'' said
Dr. Charles H. Kellner, a professor of psychiatry at the Medical
University of South Carolina in Charleston.

   Indeed, Tretter consulted Sanford only once during the torments
that followed Katie's birth because her health plan, which covered
medication, would not pay for psychotherapy. Her plan changed by
the time she became pregnant again, so she was able to visit
Sanford six times during the first trimester, when she was taken
off the medication. (As commonly happens, the depression returned
with renewed strength; Tretter quickly went back on Zoloft.)

   But the most likely alternative for women facing mood and
anxiety disorders during pregnancy and afterward may turn out to be
no help at all. It is remarkably common for them to feel ashamed of
being ``bad'' mothers, and to keep their feelings to themselves _
and for their doctors not to ask.

   (Lois B. Morris writes the Mood News column for ``Allure''
magazine.)
